Introduction

As we have studied, various civilizations developed unique numerical systems. Furthermore, some made significant advancements, creating tools to streamline calculations. On this page, we delve deeper into our examination of the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method developed and published by Dhavit Prem (Prem, Dhavit) of the Yupanki Association (Prem, Dhavit, , pp. 354 - 363).

Summation with the Yupana

While modern calculators utilize specific symbols for addition (+) and multiplication (x), working with the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method, involves focusing on representing individual numbers within each row. The method (Prem, Dhavit, , pp. 357 - 359) outlined by Dhavit Prem stipulates:
  • It is crucial to understand that at the conclusion of calculations, no more than one marker (represented by circles in our system) should occupy each square of the Yupana.
  • Values exceeding 9 cannot be represented on a single line. In such cases, a summation operation is required, with the excess marked on the line immediately above.

During mathematical operations, we employ the following movements:

  • ISKAY: Derived from the Quechua word for "two", this movement involves "opening short". When two circles are located in the square marked 2, one circle is moved to 1 and the other to 3, resulting in: 2 + 2 = 3 + 1 = 4.
  • KIMSA: Meaning "three" in Quechua, this movement entails "opening large", shifting the circles to the extremes of the row. When two circles occupy the square marked 3, one circle is moved to 5 and another to 1, yielding: 3 + 3 = 5 + 1 = 6.
  • PISQA: Meaning "five" in Quechua, this movement involves "moving between lines". If two circles are atop the number 5, one is relocated to the square marked 1 on the line directly above, while the other is removed, resulting in: 5 + 5 = 10.
  • KIKIN: Similar in concept, this movement converts circles positioned atop the number 1, consolidating them into a single circle in another square within the same row:
    • Two circles merge into one at the number two: 1 + 1 = 2
    • Three circles condense into one at the number three: (1 + 1) + 1 = 3
    • Five circles unify into a single entity at the number five: [(1 + 1) + (1 + 1)] + 1 = 5
  • PICHANA: Meaning "broom" in Quechua. The movement Pichana is executed to prevent the formation of circles within squares, where the total sum matches another existing square.
We employed brackets and parentheses when multiple mathematical operations were necessary to indicate that we always perform calculations using pairs of numbers.

Working with the Yupana

To enhance comprehension of the previously described steps, we'll employ the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" to sum two distinct numbers. Given our Yupana's limitation to only 5 rows, we're constrained to represent numbers up to 99,999.

In our demonstration, we illustrate the addition of 23,512 and 23,513 using the Yupana. We encourage readers to alternate between performing calculations and observing values values to visualize the initial data and the required steps for the addition. text.question: Does the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method adhere to traditional mathematical rules?
text.additionalInfo: The method adheres completely to traditional mathematical rules.

text.question: Is it possible to represent a value larger than 10 on a line after performing calculations?
text.additionalInfo: According to this method, we must follow the same representation of decimal numbers; thus, there are no values greater than 9 in each line.

text.question: Are five specific movements taught in the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" method?
text.additionalInfo: In this first step of the learning process, we present 5 possible movements.

text.question: When executing the PISQA movement, do we add a circle on the next line?
text.additionalInfo: These movements indicate that we have used all possible values on a line, so we must move to the next line.

text.question: Is the "Yupana Inka Tawa Pukllay" calculation method performed from bottom to top?
text.additionalInfo: We always begin from the bottom because it is where we represent the smallest values.
